comments.commentBody: What happens if Congressman Mick Mulvaney is not confirmed?  For President-elect Trump, worst scenario, what if half his nominations are not confirmed? If we have grid-lock "government" at the starting line, will the government go anywhere? The corollary, if all the nominations go through and the advocated policy is to say no to everything positive accomplished in the last 8 years, then will the government go anywhere? When a 2 year old throws a temper tantrum and says no to everything, the child learns both the power of "no" and the reality of deprivation. It is easy to say "no" and deprive; any 2 year-old can do that. It takes more maturity to share and be fair and exercise citizenship with all citizens in mind. I have written this before because it has become like a mantra for me, in the pledge of allegiance to the United States Flag we say it stands for "liberty and justice for all". That is the standard by which I will measure this next Administration and Congress.

Government spending on the common wealth and private citizen spending are what keep the community running.  We used to understand that a necessary balance needs to exist.  Under Republican greedthink this goes out the window and is why under Republican administrations for the past 30 years the nation as a whole does not do well.  When you spend government money as on wars without taxing for it or when you cut government spending at a time of weakish consumer spending you set off a negative economic spiral within the nation, and workers whose incomes have been essentially flat for 20 years are not in a position to fill the loss in the economy.  That is what has happened in Kansas and other Republican states which have followed this economically ignorant practice.  But Rs don't believe in reality until it hits their 1%, which is to say not until a depression sets in.  It gets really exhausting, trying to show reality to those who don't have to care about it because their money allows them to create their own reality.

Hard to imagine how an economy with such a low rate of unemployment can "Make America Great Again" or was that "Make America Grate Again". My bets are on the latter. I give the Trump, his Cabinet and Republican Congress and Senate six months until Reality Hurts. My only fear is that as we slide down the slippery slope is that Trump will try to Twitter his way out of the chaos and go off on grand foreign adventures to distract the American public from his hubris. It will be interesting, as well as dangerous, but I predict that a sensible Congress and Senate will rein him in. Of course, then he will present his failure as a scheme agains him personally and a threat to America. What an interesting time we will have to endure the first, and hopefully last, 100 days of his Presidency.

Mulvaney will use, perhaps, the most available mechanism at his disposal: blue smoke and mirrors to do Trump's bidding. I would posit that all government programs, in their current form, if they pique the interest of Trump in some way, are at risk. He is a vindictive, retaliatory and ignorant POTUS...or will be. Converts to Trumpism, in the bureaucracy, will find a willing accomplice as they come to him with various budgetary axes to grind. As such, the cuts will be haphazard, random, personal and vicious in nature.
It will fall to the press and Congress to check this misfits behavior before he wreaks havoc that will take decades to undo.

It is tiresome reading how Trump's cabinet, full of very successful people from several fields, (many who  do not need a federal job and related headaches to make money) are all becoming involved in the new administration planning only to go to DC, make a suicide pact and destroy the county.

It's also important to remember that cutting the budget essentially cuts jobs, which, of course, reduces tax revenue. For example, I work for a company that provides medical care for individuals using Medicaid; I am not a government employee. If Medicaid is gone, so is my job. Multiply that over the entire country and lots of middle class and working class jobs will be gone.

Happy New Year, Everyone! Looks like we're in for a very bumpy ride as Trump's picks dismantle our government.

No successful, industrialized country governs by the "small government, low tax, low regulation" nonsense that Conservatives keep pushing. Because it is terrible for the economy and worse for the citizens. It simply does not work.
Why? Because one purpose of government is to provide the environment that will help citizens and businesses succeed. This not only includes the physical parts, like clean water and an efficient electrical grid, but also a healthy and educated population that can maximize the benefits of that physical infrastructure. The GOP seems to think that all of this can happen magically without any government assistance. History has not only shown that this never happens, that governments are the only ones to provide these services because there is no direct, short term profit in investing in either such things, or the citizens that populate society.

It's an indisputable fact that any government expenditure is paid for either by taxation or borrowing. The corollary is that any reduction in such spending either reduces debt obligation or leaves more money in the had of taxpayers who likely know better how to efficiently use their resources.

I'm pretty sure every budget chief in history understands this, but it's rare to have one that cares.

As a constituent from Mulvaney's district in SC, I can verify the accuracy of this editorial.  In addition to what was said here, Mulvaney is a complete toady for the entire conservative package including American's for Prosperity, The Heritage Foundation etc.  He even jumped on the bandwagon when they were trying to get rid of the Export-Import bank.  He posted about that for weeks and most of his constituents don't even know what it is.  You could not have found a worse pick. During the height of the great recession when we needed some stimulus spending Mulvaney was all about belt tightening.  Look where that got Europe.

I believe President Obama had a bipartisan commission to deal with both taxes and spending. Simpson/Bowles was rejected on a bi-partisan basis and President Obama didn't push it.

Nobody knows what the federal debt will be. We do know we need a budget and taxes that reflect the needs of the budget. Both parties have fully rejected that premise.

This article reflects the direction that the Trump administration's financial power and influence could, and most probably will, take.

Is it not time as a practical matter, in addition to the necessary examination of all the aspects of the Trump administration as it develops and proceeds, that all the people of the United States, and, perhaps the world, take a step back and prepare themselves to live under a government that may have no interest in governance, international relations, political thought and practice, concern for all the people, and with no regard for many of the ideals, policies, and actions that the United States has had throughout its history?

America has always had a specialness and greatness to it. It does not follow that making America great again by hopefully trying to make it richer or spending less money will necessarily make the lives of its people sustainable or better.
